properties.name: Boston Light
properties.description: Posted by MikettThis is the Boston Harbor Lighthouse on Little Brewster Island. The island is so small you can see it on the satellite, but it\'s not on the map. You can get a free tour of the lighthouse July 4th weekends!

properties.name: Christopher Columbus Park
properties.description: Posted by Mikett   boston, maThis is a pleasant little park hidden along the waterfront in Boston. Boston Ahts has a nice little arts festival here in the summer time.

properties.name: Customs House
properties.description: Posted by MikettOnce upon a time the Customs House used to be the tallest building in Boston. It is one of my favorite buildings archetecturally speaking. Currently it is a Marriott Hotel.

properties.name: Fort Washington
properties.description: Posted by MikettThis is Fort Washington. It\'s only a small little hill with a few mounds where canon once sat. It\'s not particularly exciting, but, for some reason I find the fact that there is this practically unknown Revolutionary War site nestled among the rundown factories and MIT dorms. As I recall, this is one of the sites where Washington bombed Boston w hen it was held by the British, but I could have that wrong.

properties.name: Hidden Garden
properties.description: Posted by MikettThis garden is off the beaten path a bit, but is right off the Harbor Walk. I\'m not sure if it is public or private, but I\'ve never been kicked out. There are several decrepit benches and even a small fountain to be had.

properties.name: Holocaust Memorial
properties.description: Posted by MikettThe Holocaust Memorial is very well done and moving. Right behind it is Haymarket, the buzzing outdoor market.

properties.name: Longfellow Bridge
properties.description: Posted by MikettThis bridge, known officially as the Longfellow Bridge, is also called the \'Salt & Pepper\' bridge for obvious reasons. The bases of the various \'salt & pepper shakers\' are in the shape of Viking ships. Myth has it that the Vikings got about as far south as Boston back before Columbus, though I don\'t think there\'s any archeological basis for this.

properties.name: Old Ironsides
properties.description: Posted by MikettOld Ironsides

properties.name: Paul Revere's Landing
properties.description: Posted by MikettThis is the site where Paul Revere landed on his way from Boston to warn the colonists that the British were coming. He was met here, got a horse, and then was caught by British soldiers somewhere along the line.

properties.name: Postoffice Square
properties.description: Posted by MikettAnother nicely landscaped bit of green amidst the buildings of Boston.

properties.name: Rock above Rockport
properties.description: Posted by MikettThis headland above Rockport Harbor is a nice place to sit and enjoy some quiet time. There is a small walkway that leads up from Atlantic Ave. Often you see families scrambling over the rocks, and once I even got an impromptu concert as a man practiced playing his flute.

properties.name: Rockport Harbor
properties.description: Posted by MikettRockport is a beautiful little town to spend a summer day at! Lots of little shops and fun things to do. From this little roundabout you can see everything around you.

properties.name: Rooftop Garden
properties.description: Posted by Mikett  This is a pleasantly landscaped garden on the top of the Marriott in Kendall Square.

properties.name: Royal Crescent
properties.description: Posted by MikettBeautiful archetecture

properties.name: Singing Beach
properties.description: Posted by Mikett  Singing Beach, Manchester By the Sea, MA. this is a beautiful little beach only a 10 minute walk from the Commuter Rail stop

properties.name: Trinity Church
properties.description: Posted by MikettThis is a beautiful old church. Well worth spending the money on the guided tour. :)

properties.name: Washington Memorial, Mt. Auburn Cemetery
properties.description: Posted by Mikett A memorial to George Washington up on the top of a hill at Mt. Auburn Cemetery

properties.name: Whirlygig
properties.description: Posted by MikettThis is a piece of public art brought to you by the city of Cambridge. It\'s a large, colorful whirlygig that partially rotates in the wind.
